BusinessOfficerGrp.PersonTitleTxt: Vice President of Business and Fina

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: The College is an institution of higher education and provides instruction and various support services in achieving its purpose.
IRS990.MissionDesc: The College is an institution of higher education and provides instruction and various support services in achieving its purpose.
IRS990.Desc: To sustain a learning community in which students can prepare academically, socially and spiritually for leadership in a complex, diverse and rapidly changing world.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Auxiliary Enterprises support the Colleges mission of providing quality educational opportunities. These services include, but are not limited to food service, housing, campus post office, parking, vending, campus stores and athletics.

Form990PartVIISectionAGrp.PersonNm: The Reverend Dr Alvin O Jackson

Form990PartVIISectionAGrp.TitleTxt: Vice President of Facilities and Real Property Management
Executive Director of the Owens Health, Wellness and Human Resources Center
Vice President of Information Technology / Chief Information Officer

ProgramServiceRevenueGrp.Desc: Sales and Services of Auxiliary Enterprises

OtherSecuritiesGrp.Desc: Financial derivatives and other financial products

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The endowment funds shown are considered permanently restricted. The College does not intend to use the funds.

The Colleges policy is to record a liability for any tax position taken that is beneficial to the College, including any related interest and penalties, when it is more-likely-than-not the position taken by management with respect to a transaction or class of transactions will be overturned by a taxing authority upon examination. The College is subject to income tax on its unrelated business activity, which is WLOO television station. As a result, the accrued taxes payable as of June 20, 2018 is 0. Currently, there are no years under examination by any taxing authority.

The campus is home to the Academic Civil Rights Research Center, which houses many artifacts from the civil rights movement in Mississippi. The displays are used for public exhibition, but more importantly for the education of future generations seeking knowledge of the past.

On March 16, 2018, the College received notification from the U.S. Department of Education that the full balance of the bonds payable was forgiven and related collateral released pursuant to the Secretarys authority under Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018. Accordingly, all related transactions were removed from the Colleges financial statements resulting in a net nonoperating gain of 25,915,500.

The College offers scholarships and student financial aid to assist with meeting the students financial obligations. The Financial Aid Office has the necessary policies and procedures to ensure that the College adheres to and complies with federal regulations regarding eligibility for student financial aid. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend on other factors such as grade point average, family income or athletic talents.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required Uniform Guidance audit annually.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The College presents the Form 990 to its Finance/Audit Committee for review when the form is ready. Depending on when the committee meets and the due date of the return, the Form 990 is either modified before it is filed or an amendment is filed for any changes required by the Finance/Audit Committees review.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Trustees are required to disclose at the next convening Board of Trustees meeting any conflicts of interest. Trustees with a conflict of interest on a matter of vote must abstain from voting. The Colleges Audit Committee is responsible for ensuring adherence to the policy.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Board of Trustees, based on predetermined areas of performance evaluates the work of the President annually. The Boards Evaluation and Compensation Committee evaluates the performance. When additional compensation is deemed appropriate, a review of the salaries at peer institutions is conducted to assist in arriving at a recommendation to the Executive Committee for approval.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Compensation for top officers of the College is at the discretion of the President. This discretion is based on 1 previous salary history, 2 market data from CUPA survey published by the Chronicle of Higher Education and 3 the bargaining process.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The College makes is governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements available to the public upon request. To obtain copies, contact the Business Office and submit a request identifying the specific documents.
The College presents its changes in net assets or fund balances separate from revenues and expenses. The balance is representative of gains and losses on investments during the fiscal year.

On March 16, 2018, the College received notification from the U.S. Department of Education that the full balance of the bonds payable was forgiven and related collateral released pursuant to the Secretarys authority under Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018. Accordingly, all related transactions were removed from the Colleges financial statements resulting in a net nonoperating gain of 25,915,500.
